title: Long-Term Effects of Cisplatin and Cranial Radiation Therapy on Hearing
chief_complaint: The patient presented with perceived bilateral hearing loss which he attributed to chemotherapy. He also reported tinnitus in the left ear and difficulties communicating.

problem_summary.onset: Symptoms began in 2002 during treatment for nasopharyngeal cancer.
problem_summary.course: Progressive deterioration over 10 years, with both sensorineural decline and fluctuating conductive components.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tinnitus (left ear), aural fullness, chronic otitis media with effusion, ear drainage.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant difficulty communicating, reduced benefit from hearing aids over time, difficulty recognizing speech even in quiet.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Currently considering all options to improve communication, including personal infrared hearing assistive technology.

history.present_illness: Patient is a survivor of nasopharyngeal cancer diagnosed in June 2002. Treated with concurrent cisplatin and radiation therapy (July-October 2002). Reported hearing loss, tinnitus, and communication difficulties during treatment.
history.otologic_history: History of chronic serous otitis media; PE tube placed in right TM in 2002. Intermittent Eustachian tube dysfunction.
history.noise_exposure_history: No significant history of noise exposure.
history.medical_psych_history: Squamous cell carcinoma of the nasopharynx.
history.prior_management: No baseline audiogram was performed prior to cancer treatment.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetric mild sloping to moderate SNHL through 750 Hz, sloping to moderately severe SNHL at 1000-8000 Hz. Air-bone gap present in left ear at 250-500 Hz.

numeric_results.Right_AC_Thresholds: Approx 30-40 dB HL sloping to 70-80 dB HL
numeric_results.Left_AC_Thresholds: Approx 30-40 dB HL sloping to 70-80 dB HL

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs reveal moderate loss. WRS shows slight difficulty in the right ear and normal ability in the left ear.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Flat configuration with large ear canal volume (consistent with patent PE tube). Left ear: Hypocompliant with negative pressure.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent bilaterally at 500 to 4000 Hz to contralateral and ipsilateral stimulation.

history.present_illness: 5 years post-cancer diagnosis. Review of previous exams confirmed this was the first showing significant decrease in bone and air conduction thresholds at 3000 Hz and above without known middle ear involvement.
history.otologic_history: Intermittent otitis media with effusion continued over the years.
history.medical_psych_history: Patient was extremely ill during the 3-year gap (2004-2007) and only scheduled office visits as needed.
history.prior_management: Fitted with bilateral BTE amplification in 2003.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Significant decrease in thresholds at 3000 Hz and above. High-frequency air conduction thresholds stable when mixed loss not evident.

numeric_results.Right_AC_Thresholds: Sloping from ~50 dB HL to ~90 dB HL
numeric_results.Left_AC_Thresholds: Sloping from ~50 dB HL to ~90 dB HL
numeric_results.BC_Thresholds_2k_4k: Consistently between 60 and 70 dB HL (2002-2004 data comparison)

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs stable compared to 2002; WRS slightly reduced in left ear compared to baseline.

history.present_illness: 10 years post-initial exam. Patient reports increased difficulty with communication and receiving less benefit from hearing aids.
history.otologic_history: Continuous bouts with chronic serous otitis media.
history.medical_psych_history: Evaluated for Cochlear Implant (CI) but decided not to pursue due to health concerns and aversion to surgery.
history.prior_management: Hearing aids reprogrammed to accommodate changes. Uses personal infrared HAT for TV.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Severe to profound mixed hearing loss in right ear; profound mixed hearing loss in left ear. No measurable response at 4000-8000 Hz bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Significant decrease bilaterally in WRS (slight difficulty to very poor ability). Greatest change occurred over past 2 years.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Could not be completed due to inability to maintain an appropriate seal.

overall_audiologic_summary: Over a 10-year period, the patient demonstrated a progressive deterioration in hearing from a mild-to-moderate sensorineural loss to a severe-to-profound mixed loss. High-frequency thresholds declined gradually, followed by a rapid decrease in low- and mid-frequency thresholds. Speech recognition scores deteriorated significantly, shifting from good/fair performance to very poor ability, necessitating reliance on visual cues and assistive technology.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss is a result of the combined effects of the chemotherapy (cisplatin) and radiation therapy you received.
The radiation has caused long-term issues with your Eustachian tubes, leading to fluid buildup that adds a 'conductive' blockage to your hearing loss.
Because speech clarity has decreased significantly, hearing aids alone may not provide clear speech understanding in all situations.
An FM system or other assistive listening devices can help improve the signal-to-noise ratio, especially for television or distance listening.
It is important to continue monitoring your hearing annually, as radiation effects can continue to evolve over many years.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is weary from a decade of medical treatments but proactive about communication.
You are frustrated that your hearing aids are helping less than they used to.
You are hesitant about further surgeries (like a cochlear implant) because of your traumatic medical history.
You rely heavily on lip-reading and context due to poor speech discrimination scores.
